question: Match the following:
columnA: Bees, butterflies, flies, beetles, wasps, ants, moths, birds (sunbirds and humming birds) and bats
Larger animals such as some primates (lemurs), arboreal rodents, reptiles (gecko lizard and garden lizard)
columnB: Common pollinating agents
Dominant biotic pollinating agents
Also reported as pollinators in some species
Specifically adapted for a particular species of animal

answer.Larger animals such as some primates (le: Also reported as pollinators in some species
answer.Flowers of animal-pollinated plants: Specifically adapted for a particular species of animal

question: Match the following:
columnA: Flowers pollinated by flies and beetles
columnB: Large, colourful, fragrant and rich in nectar
Clustered into an inflorescence to make them conspicuous
Secrete foul odours to attract these animals
Nectar and pollen grains

answer.Majority of insect-pollinated flowers: Large, colourful, fragrant and rich in nectar
answer.Small flowers: Clustered into an inflorescence to make them conspicuous
answer.Flowers pollinated by flies and beetles: Secrete foul odours to attract these animals

question: Match the following:
columnA: Pollen grains in animal pollinated flowers
Relationship between a species of moth and the plant Yucca
columnB: Gets a coating of pollen grains
Generally sticky
Safe place to lay eggs; flower is about 6 feet in height
Both species cannot complete their life cycle without each other

answer.Body of the animal visitor: Gets a coating of pollen grains
answer.Floral reward in Amorphophallus: Safe place to lay eggs; flower is about 6 feet in height
answer.Relationship between a species of moth a: Both species cannot complete their life cycle without each other

question: Match the following:
columnA: Pollen release and stigma receptivity not synchronised
Anther and stigma placed at different positions
columnB: Prevents autogamy by releasing pollen before stigma is receptive or vice versa
Prevents autogamy by avoiding contact of pollen with stigma of same flower
Genetic mechanism preventing self-pollen from fertilising ovules
Prevents autogamy; in dioecy prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy

answer.Pollen release and stigma receptivity no: Prevents autogamy by releasing pollen before stigma is receptive or vice versa
answer.Anther and stigma placed at different po: Prevents autogamy by avoiding contact of pollen with stigma of same flower
answer.Self-incompatibility: Genetic mechanism preventing self-pollen from fertilising ovules
answer.Unisexual flowers: Prevents autogamy; in dioecy prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy

question: Match the following:
columnA: Monoecious plants such as castor and maize
columnB: Male and female flowers on same plant; prevents autogamy but not geitonogamy
Male and female flowers on different plants; prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy
Rejected by pistil
Accepted by pistil and promotes post-pollination events

answer.Monoecious plants such as castor and mai: Male and female flowers on same plant; prevents autogamy but not geitonogamy
answer.Dioecious plants such as papaya: Male and female flowers on different plants; prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy
answer.Right type of pollen: Accepted by pistil and promotes post-pollination events
